Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will improve outcomes of assisted reproductive technologies by allowing a more effective method to select high quality embryos to transfer. Incorporating embryo transfer into livestock breeding programs to maximize superior genetic traits can be economically advantageous to producers. However, the only currently available means to select which embryo to transfer is subjective, invasive or expensive. As most livestock producers cannot justify the cost of these available methods into their programs, the transfer of dead and low quality embryos into recipients, which will never establish a pregnancy, is common. The technology developed with this project involves a noninvasive, cost-effective and quantitative method to select embryo viability and quality. Using this technology to select which embryo to transfer will result in increased pregnancy rates after embryo transfer. This technology will reduce costs spent on transferring non-viable embryos and caring for non-pregnant recipient animals. This technology also provides the only published method to select which embryos have survived cryopreservation. This I-Corps project can increase the efficiency of embryo transfer and cryopreservation of mammalian embryos in a livestock production setting.

This I-Corps project investigates the commercial potential of research demonstrating early embryo growth potential can be determined by an embryos specific gravity. This I-Corps technology measures the rate of an embryos descent through a media filled chamber. The embryos descent rate provides insight to intracellular properties based on density of intracellular constituents, which cannot be estimated through standard embryo selection techniques. For example, a non-viable embryo has lost the ability of its membrane to regulate what enters and exits the cell. The cell will then move towards equilibrium with the media and water will enter the cell. This increases the cellular density of the dead embryo, and results in a faster descent time than the descent time of a live embryo. Studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of this technology to distinguish live from dead embryos in mouse zygotes, mouse cryopreserved blastocysts and cryopreserved sheep blastocysts. Additional studies have demonstrated the technology does not harm embryos, as embryos continue development and establish healthy pregnancies after measured with the specific gravity device.

Institution.Name: Texas Tech University Health Science Center
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER

Performance_Institution.Name: Texas Tech University Health Science Center

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the NSF I-Corps cohort, the team conducted 231 customer interviews.

The team attended the National Cattleman’s Beef Association meeting in Phoenix, AZ, the World Ag Expo in Tulare, CA, the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo in Houston, TX, a Livestock auction in Salida, CO and met with the reproductive physiology unit at the San Diego Zoo. Additionally, the team met with customers in California, Texas, Georgia, and Colorado to explore customer values and pain points.

 

    In effort to protect the intellectual property of the technology, the following patents have been filed to protect the method, device and use of the technology:

 

Patents Pending: 

 

Prien, S.D., Penrose. L. and Wessels, C. System for Determining Embryo Viability (PCT #143350.010701, filed June 30th, 2015)

 

Prien S.D., Penrose, L. and Wessels, C. Use of a non-invasive technique of embryo assessment to determine embryo sex. (PCT 62/650638 filed March 30, 2018)

 

Rangel, R., Wells, J., Embryo selection and method of use (Application # 15485683, filed April 12th, 2017)

 

Rangel, R., Wells, J., Embryo selection and method of use (Application # 62562639, filed September 25th, 2017)

 

Embryotics, LLC was formed by Dr. Cara Wessels, Robert Rangel, Justin Wells and Charles Baker. Embryotics, LLC filed “Embryo Selection System and Method of Use” and has signed and executed a license agreement for “System for Determining Embryo Viability” from Texas Tech University. Embryotics has signed and executed option agreement for “Use of a noninvasive technique of embryo assessment to determine embryo sex” to grant Embryotics first right to license the technology for embryo sexing purposes.  In the license agreement, Embryotics will pay a 5% royalty to Texas Tech University.

 

Prior to participation in the I-Corps Program, a NSF SBIR Grant was submitted in December of 2017.  This submission was declined funding.  The team recognizes the NSF I-Corps program allowed tremendous learning and growth.  Dr. Cara Wessels and Robert Rangel have resubmitted a proposal for a NSF SBIR grant in July of 2018, which includes information learned from customer discovery and a more refined plan for commercialization. Dr. Cara Wessels and Robert Rangel will also submit to the USDA SBIR in October of 2018.

 

Embryotics placed 8th at the Rice Business Plan Competition in April of 2018 out of 42 teams and over 750 applicants. The team won $42,000 in prizes. Embryotics won 1st place and the People’s Choice Award at the Texas Tech University iLaunch Competition for a total of $11,000 in prizes supported from the Lubbock Economic Development Alliance. Embryotics was accepted into the Texas Tech Accelerator program, which granted the company a $25,000 award and a 12- month structured curriculum and mentorship.  This Accelerator is directed by the teams I-Corps industry mentor, Kimberly Gramm. Additionally, the team was accepted and offered investment by the Cicada GrowLab Incubator in Sydney, Australia, but declined the offer to focus on commercialization development in the United States. The company is currently seeking investment opportunities to further enhance their growth.  Dr. Wessels et al., has a publication currently under review entitled “A non-invasive means to determine oocyte competency” and is actively working with a group to perform a comprehensive sex selection trial. Dr. Wessels attended the Beef Improvement Federation meeting in Loveland, CO in June and is continuing customer discovery to further develop a company strategy for commercialization. Dr. Wessels has served as a panelist for two I-Corps kickoff workshops in San Antonio, TX and Austin, TX. Dr. Wessels also collaborated with J.R. Simplot Animal Science in Kuna, ID to perform a non-invasive sex selection study to further investigate additional uses of the technology.

 


Last Modified: 08/27/2018
Modified by: Samuel Prien

Images (1 of )
  • Once in a lifetime opportunity to interview Dr. Barbara Durrant and her team at the San Diego Zoo. We got to tag along as the ultrasound the endangered Southern White Rhinoceros.
    Cara Wessels
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Samuel Prien
    Interview at San Diego Zoo
  • Robert and Cara ran into another I-Corps team from our cohort performing customer discovery at the World Ag Expo in Tulare, CA.
    Cara Wessels
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Samuel Prien
    Encounter with Fellow I-Corps Team
  • We learned a lot about the diary industry when interviewing customers involved in breeding Jersey cows.
    Cara Wessels
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Samuel Prien
    Interview with the US Jersey Association Team
  • Learned a lot about show stock at the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo. Cara and Robert even had the opportunity to interview camel breeders.
    Cara Wessels
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Samuel Prien
    Interviews at the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo
